headline.main: Can Kraft Trim the Fat In an Oreo World?

docs.abstract: Food industry experts are skeptical about recent pledge by Kraft Foods to help fight global epidemic of obesity; even Kraft officials, who have vowed to reduce portion sizes and cut fat calories of some products, are playing down some of their planned changes; food experts say that while food companies have increasingly offered healthier alternatives, consumers continue to favor snacks and products with tasty fats and sugars; Kraft's research and development team is looking to remove fat and sugar from some of company's popular items without compromising taste; charts; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Three weeks ago, Kraft Foods Inc., the nation's largest food company, said it was going to help fight a global epidemic -- obesity. Now comes the hard part. How does the maker of Oreo cookies, Velveeta cheese, Tombstone Pizza and Oscar Mayer wieners actually help trim waistlines? And can a food giant profit from selling people on the idea of eating less?

headline.main: Expert Panel Finds Flaws In Diet Pill Safety Study

byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and FORD FESSENDEN

docs.abstract: House subcommittee releases documents showing that panel of scientists has found flaws in medical study that some ephedra companies have touted as showing product is safe and helpful for losing weight; FDA had to make unusual deal to get access to industry data from study, agreeing to hire outside experts for review (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: As a growing number of deaths and illnesses have raised questions about their diet pills, some ephedra companies have promoted a medical study as showing that their product is safe and helpful for losing weight. But documents released yesterday by a House subcommittee show that a panel of scientists has found flaws and shortcomings in the study. Some government officials said those problems could undercut its safety findings at a time when federal regulators are trying to decide if they should ban ephedra, an herbal stimulant, or restrict its sales.
docs.snippet: As a growing number of deaths and illnesses have raised questions about their diet pills, some ephedra companies have promoted a medical study as showing that their product is safe and helpful for losing weight.     But documents released yesterday...

byline.original: By PRISCILLA CHAN and ANDREA PERELMAN

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students learn the definition of a suggested serving size and re-define their daily food intake in terms of these recommended amounts.
docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students learn the definition of a suggested serving size and re-define their daily food intake in terms of these recommended amounts.

docs.abstract: America's obsession with food is outlined in terms of environmental factors of availability, advertising, price, variety and portion size; researchers have found controlled eating goes way beyond personal willpower; chart on portion size shows 1954 hamburger weighed only 3.9 ounces as compared to 12.6 ounce Double Whopper today, and combined with discount pricing, consumers almost feel compelled to consume more; Yale Professor Dr Kelly D Brownell labels American society toxic food environment because of rampant overeating and research now confirms large portions are component in equation; food industry lawsuits have emerged with many calling for fast food reforms; Kraft Foods announces intention to reduce portion sizes for some products in support of healthier eating; many studies point to disconnect between consumer's concept regarding size of portion and calories; suggest overindulence is learned behavior appearing around age 5; holds that temptation to consume more makes moderation increasingly difficult; charts, photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: From giant sodas to supersize burgers to all-you-can-eat buffets, America's approach to food can be summed up by one word: Big. Plates are piled high, and few crumbs are left behind. Today's blueberry muffin could, in an earlier era, have fed a family of four.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 U.S. Troops Land in Liberia As Fighting Engulfs Capital United States marines arrived to protect the American Embassy and evacuate foreigners from the Liberian capital of Monrovia as fighting raged and as residents lay bodies of their loved ones at the shuttered gate to the embassy. By day's end, reports from hospitals and clinics suggested that roughly 90 Liberians had been killed and more than 360 had been wounded. A1 The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, joined West African leaders in imploring the Bush administration to send peacekeepers to Liberia. Administration officials resisted, insisting that Liberia's neighbors take the lead in stabilizing the country, and calling on rebels and the government of President G. Charles Taylor to respect a cease-fire agreement. A3
